Pensionado Visa for Uruguayans

Complete guide to obtaining the Pensionado Visa (Retirement Visa) as a Uruguayan citizen. Specific requirements, timeline, and process for Uruguay passport holders.

Overview for Uruguayan Citizens

The Pensionado Visa is specifically designed for retirees receiving pension income from their home country. This is a subset of the Rentista category but specifically optimized for retirees. As a Uruguayan citizen, you have visa-free entry to Argentina for 90 days that affect your pathway to this visa.

Special Considerations for Uruguayans:

  • â€¢The Uruguay-Argentina tax treaty helps prevent double taxation on your pension/investment income.

Is This Visa Right for You?

The Pensionado Visa is designed for:

  • Retirees receiving government or private pensions
  • People with social security income
  • Those with company pension plans
  • Individuals with 401k/RRIF distributions (if structured as pension)
  • Anyone with verifiable pension income

Requirements for Uruguayans

Income Requirement

Proof of minimum $1,000-1,500 USD monthly pension income

Additional Requirements

  • â€¢ Official pension documentation
  • â€¢ Pension must be stable and ongoing
  • â€¢ Valid passport
  • â€¢ Clean criminal record (apostilled)
  • â€¢ Proof of address in Argentina

Document Checklist for Uruguayans

As a Uruguayan citizen, you'll need these documents:

  • Valid passport
  • Official pension documentation
  • Bank statements showing pension deposits
  • Criminal background check (apostilled)
  • Birth certificate (apostilled)
  • Passport photos
  • Proof of address in Argentina

Timeline & Process

Processing Time

60-90 days

Visa Duration

1 year (renewable)

Path to Citizenship

After 2 years, eligible for permanent residency â†’ citizenship

Step-by-Step Process

1

Entry to Argentina

Uruguayans can enter visa-free for 90 days. Use this time to prepare your application.

2

Gather Documents

Obtain all required documents from Uruguay.

3

Submit Application

Apply at the DirecciÃ³n Nacional de Migraciones (DNM) in Buenos Aires or your local migraciones office.

4

Receive Precaria

You'll receive a temporary authorization (precaria) allowing you to stay legally while processing.

5

Collect Residency Card

Once approved, collect your DNI (residency card) and enjoy your new life in Argentina!

Costs

Government Fee$300-500 USD
Legal Fees (optional)$800-2,000 USD
Total Estimated Cost$1,100-2,500 USD

Pros & Cons

Advantages

  • +Lower income threshold than general Rentista
  • +Designed specifically for retirees
  • +Can work if desired
  • +Access to retiree benefits in Argentina
  • +Path to permanent residency and citizenship

Considerations

  • â€¢Must have verifiable pension income
  • â€¢Pension documentation must be official
  • â€¢Annual renewal required

Frequently Asked Questions

What if I have pension plus other income?

If your pension meets the minimum threshold, you qualify. Additional income is fine. If pension alone doesn't meet threshold, consider the general Rentista visa.

Can I work part-time as a retiree?

Yes, the Pensionado Visa doesn't restrict employment, so you can work if you choose.
